Art and the Sharing Economy

By Amy on 17 November 2015 in Chicago

Tweet

How today’s sharing economy is influencing the production and consumption of art.

“We couldn’t have existed ten years ago, before Facebook, because people weren’t really into sharing,” one of Airbnb’s founders, Nate Blecharczyk, has said. He has a point. People are willing to share just about everything today: renting a room in someone’s home through Airbnb or a bike with Divvy, Chicago’s “bike sharing system;” others are content sharing pictures of lavish vacations or unique experiences on social media. This sharing mentality coincides with today’s sharing economy, which is upending production and consumption behaviors in the arts.

Helen Molesworth, an art historian and curator, made a compelling observation between art and the post-war American economy in her essay, “Work Ethic.” She argues that post-World War II avant garde art corresponded with the changing post-war American economy, from a manufacturing economy to a post-industrial one grounded in services and managerial labor. That is, from producing goods to overseeing the labor of others, she explains, and offers this example: Conceptual artists relied on language and directions for others to complete, thereby functioning like a manager; other artists gave themselves tasks, and performed them. Renouncing traditional artistic materials to produce an art object, “artists came to see themselves . . . as workers in capitalist America.”

Merging Technology and Art

By Amy on 11 November 2015 in Chicago

Tweet

The “Feel Flows” exhibition at Fernwey gallery reveals how today’s digital and physical worlds are merging.

It is no surprise that technology is infiltrating life today. The internet and social media have had a revolutionary impact, but these technologies are just the beginning of what is to come. The debut of self-driving cars, the Internet of Things and improvements to virtual reality have the potential to upend life as we know it. Indeed our digital and physical worlds are colliding.

The “Feel Flows” exhibition at Fernwey gallery in Chicago captures this merge. The show consists of Katie Pennachio’s paintings and Matt Mancini’s sculptures, along with an edition series each artist made in collaboration with the gallery in a different medium. Despite the physical presence of their artwork, a digital aesthetic emanates. Both artists incorporate digital technologies in their practices, and their influence is demonstrated here.

Nature Transformed

By Amy on 02 November 2015 in Chicago

Tweet

A group show at Chicago Art Source Gallery reveals the reflective side of nature.

Artists have incorporated nature in art for centuries. Some artists today use art to draw awareness to environmental issues. Impressionists captured landscapes, public recreation in city and country life and atmospheric effects and industry, among other scenes. Notably, though, Romantic artists depicted nature’s power, extremes and volatility—reacting to the Enlightenment’s emphasis on order and the consequences of the French Revolution, explains the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

The thirty-some paintings that make up “Nature Transformed” at Chicago Art Source Gallery seem to respond to global events through nature once again. Today’s world is plagued by global distress with issues surrounding immigration and the Syrian Civil War as of late. Instead of the imagination and emotional fervor that filled Romantic paintings, “Nature Transformed” offers a quieting, transcendental experience—suitable for poignant times.

Germination

By Amy on 25 October 2015 in Chicago

Tweet

A group show at LVL3 in Chicago brings together three artists that explore germination in multiple ways.

Visitors attending the “Germination” exhibition at LVL3, a gallery in Chicago, should expect to be surprised by the connections the show offers. The title brings to mind seeds growing into plants. But the visitor cannot help thinking how the term germination has expanded after seeing an amalgamation of works created by Heidi Norton, Derrick Piens and Timothy Bergstrom. Although most of the fourteen pieces displayed elicit a reference to nature, the multiple perspectives and different media each artist use demonstrates a broader application of germination.

The diversity of the art contained under the germination theme reflects Chicago's current art and cultural endeavors, making “Germination” timely. The exhibition opened on the heels of EXPO Chicago, an international modern and contemporary art fair, and before the inaugural Chicago Architecture Biennial (CAB), which began October 3. More broadly, the 2012 Chicago Cultural Plan, an initiative of Chicago’s Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events, is central to Chicago’s advancement “as a global destination for creativity, innovation and excellence in the arts,” the organization claims. CAB, for instance, is a result of this plan. In this context, germination is a relevant exhibition theme for a city implementing initiatives dedicated to Chicago’s culture and economic development. Fittingly, Norton, Piens and Bergstrom each offer a distinct lens to consider the topic of growth and transformation. Here is art that brings meaning and relevance to the outside world.
